node.text:
As I travel this week, I was inspired by a beautiful @TED Talk from @taiye.entirely that encourages us to ask not where you are from but where you are local, and that resonated with me. Where we're from can be quite a limiting descriptor, whereas where we are local tells a fascinating story about where we feel at home, with whom we form our relationships, what rituals and cultural customs we hold dear and what restrictions dictate how we move through these places. 

Through the lens of this last year, we may have been "at home" but perhaps we didn't feel at home, as we were disconnected from the experiences that make a place feel familiar and resonant. So, I'm curious, not where you're from, but where do you feel local? 
To listen to Taiye's exploration of this topic, visit the link in my bio.

node.text:
I’m hearing a lot about burnout lately, from friends, clients and colleagues. It seems that many of us are in need of a break right now. 

As I take a moment of vacation, I am reminding myself (and all of you) that a break is freedom from any “must do”. It’s not a chance to do all the things I’ve been neglecting but an opportunity to just be, releasing the need to produce and optimize, and instead allowing life to happen around me. By relinquishing agency, I can truly relax.

node.text:
We’re asking ourselves many questions right now as we rediscover how we relate to one another. Should we gather? Is it safe? And once we’re together, what can we ask? What can we tell? So much has happened in the last 18 months, that we long to deepen our conversations past the surface. 

For more on reconnection, listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on his podcast On Purpose.

It's not a permanent state of enthusiasm. Love is something that you actively cultivate.

Listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on this week's episode of On Purpose wherever you get your podcasts.

node.text:
This couple came to talk about the deep conflict and the secrets that they both carry surrounding their work. One person can't talk about what she does and one person can't talk about the fact that he no longer wants to do what he does.

Season 2 of #HowsWorkPodcast is now available on all platforms.

🎧 Listen to If I Quit, What Will People Say? on Spotify or wherever you get your podcasts.

For show notes and transcripts, visit estherperel.com/podcast

node.text:
This is the story of #WhereShouldWeBegin, the game. 

The pandemic left us missing intimacy and play, so I created a game to help us rediscover both. Designed for partners, dates, or friends, Where Should We Begin? is many games at once. I have played it with my team, my family, and my oldest friends. And each time we have discovered something new about each other.

To preorder the game, visit estherperel.com/thegame or click the link in my profile bio.

For the time being, we are only shipping to the United States. We will ship internationally in the future — stay tuned.

node.text:
@rachelbotsman defines trust as “a confident engagement with the unknown.”

In relationships, trust isn’t a promise to never hurt each other. It’s the risk that we will hurt each other and the confidence that, if we do, we will come together to heal. We will support one another. We will be kind. We will have each others’ backs. And it’s not just something that happens because we’ve decided to be together, or to move in, or to say “I do.”

Cultivating that level of trust requires millions of micro-risks that show us we’re not foolish for being confident in our relationship. It requires taking risks together that show us our partner isn’t the same as the people from our past who hurt us. Most importantly, trust requires taking risks together that help us grow into better partners for each other.

Here are five small micro-risks to help build trust in your relationships:

Go outside and say hello to the strangers you pass.
Compliment someone on something specific.
Call your friend who’s been feeling blue and leave voicemails even if know they won’t respond.
Tell your partner you’re taking them on a date even if you know they’d rather watch TV.
Tell your partner something about yourself that they don’t know. (This is one of my favorite exercises in therapy.)

This clip is an excerpt from this week's #LettersFromEsther workshop: Risk-Taking and Trust. To watch the full video, visit my YouTube channel: YouTube.com/estherperel/live

node.text:
On May 20th, we will begin #7DaysForPlay. Sign up to receive daily small, sensual, playful exercises to help you practice slowing down and connecting to your erotic self.

Register for this free challenge at bitly.com/7daysforplay or by clicking the link in my profile bio.

If you know someone who may wish to join us, send them this video or tag them in the comments below.

(There is a version for people who are in a relationship and for those who are solo. I suggest choosing the option that corresponds to your relationship status, even if you won't be doing this with your partner.)

node.text:
Foreplay doesn’t need to be something that diminishes as we get older, it’s an energy that deepens as we grow. Foreplay is for play.

On the subject of anticipation, something playful is coming soon. Join me for my upcoming free audio series, The Art of Foreplay: bitly.com/7daysforplay.

#7DaysForPlay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Esther Perel on August 17, 2021 tagging @peterattiamd. May be an image of text that says '" Sexuality is a lens. It tells a story of the values the behaviors, and the attitudes towards the body and pleasure, towards power and connection, towards the division of spirit and flesh, or mind and body or all of those things. Esther Perel'.

node.text:
Sexuality is a lens.
When I first studied family therapy and couples therapy, I did so without one formal hour about sexuality. And thought how can that be? In a culture where sexuality is so central to the topic of love and relationship, how can we do couples therapy and not ever talk about it? Something is missing. At the time, the field itself oriented around the idea that sex problems were a result of relationship problems, meaning that fixing the relationship would then fix the problems in the bedroom. My thinking has always been that this is not inaccurate but there is more to the story.
In my conversation with @peterattiamd, we talk about my journey to psychotherapy, the value of our relationships with other’s for one’s sense of wellbeing and how our relationships, sexual and otherwise, can act as a mirror to recognize and heal trauma by reflecting our own maladaptive behaviors. Listen to the full conversation in the link in my bio, and let me know what you think.

node.text:
If I just quit, what will people say? 

Season 2, Episode 1 of "How's Work?" plunges us into the life of the mixed-secrets of a mixed-faith married couple. He’s a physician who can’t open up to his family about wanting out of his profession; she’s a government agent who only recently revealed to him the nature of her profession. Each partner is emotionally drained from the demands of work, with little left over to give each other. Pushed to shove by the pandemic crisis, they now face their own domestic crisis.

In this episode, we decode the stoicism that enables these two to succeed in their jobs — but not in their relationship — and propose a switch towards shared vulnerability and trust to strengthen their connection.

node.text:
August 13th, 2020 was still lockdown in New York. I spent my birthday as I would any other then, missing my friends and unsure about meeting in-person or gathering in a group. Many of us felt our mile markers missed over the course of last year, almost as if they didn't happen at all. 

So, this year, I am traveling, both to experience the places outside of New York that I also call home and to expand my worldview again after so much time in one place. On my first vacation in 2 years, I'm reminded how important it is to take these breaks to prioritize being over doing, to live poetically not just productively, to experience life through the senses not only through the mind. I've been reading fiction instead of non-fiction, novel after novel, revelling in the power of storytelling. I find myself strolling through markets and down unknown streets flâner as the French say, to meander with no intended destination. After so long, it’s required practice. It's taken nearly 2 weeks to allow my brain and body to relax, not to set goals or expectations, to be in a state of discovery, curiosity, and play. 

Tonight, we'll celebrate with dear friends in Provence: one lost the love of her life, another her mother, and another lost both parents on the same day to COVID. This is my first time being in the same room with them, knowing that celebration and grief will commingle in the space with us, as so many have experienced at holidays or special moments this year. And that's okay, because "life loves on" as @jennifer.senior.77 wrote in @theatlantic. We're all coming together to grieve, to love, to affirm life and to celebrate our relationships. Life loves on.

node.text:
We are burnt out. 
Between siloed, tense work environments, the news cycle, 18-months of COVID and the revolving door of social openings and restrictions, we are expending a great deal of energy, physical and emotional. Our bodies are in a constant state of stress.

The side of ourselves that demands safety, stability, and security lives in balance with the side of the erotic, and this past year in particular, we have honed in so much on our security needs that the hinge got snapped off from the erotic. We flattened the curve, and we flattened ourselves in the process. So what is the antidote? 

On my blog, I talk about "Why Eroticism Should Be Part of your Self-Care Plan" - how creating a pleasurable, sensual connection with ourselves can remind us that life is worth living even when we are in pain or struggling. Eroticism is regenerative, teaching us what turns us on and energizes us and what turns us off and saps our energy and liveliness. Incorporating eroticism into our self-care plans can alter our relationship with control and transform our state of being.

To learn more about specific practices and techniques, visit the link in my bio.

node.text:
As I travel this week, I was inspired by a beautiful @TED Talk from @taiye.entirely that encourages us to ask not where you are from but where you are local, and that resonated with me. Where we're from can be quite a limiting descriptor, whereas where we are local tells a fascinating story about where we feel at home, with whom we form our relationships, what rituals and cultural customs we hold dear and what restrictions dictate how we move through these places. 

Through the lens of this last year, we may have been "at home" but perhaps we didn't feel at home, as we were disconnected from the experiences that make a place feel familiar and resonant. So, I'm curious, not where you're from, but where do you feel local? 
To listen to Taiye's exploration of this topic, visit the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says '" LOVE IS A VERB It's not a permanent state of enthusiasm. It's not about finding the right person, it's about being the right person. If you just want to be dazzled, then you will have an adventure. You will be infatuated. You will have a love story, maybe, but you won't have a life story. And a ife story is different than a love story. ESTHER PEREL'.

node.text:
For those of us who jump from relationship to relationship, a pattern sometimes emerges. We pursue a new relationship for a few months while in seduction mode and then find ourselves bored, disinterested, disappointed, and looking for the next person to come along. Why? Is it because “we haven’t found the right person yet,” or is it because we’re not yet familiar with our own attachment style? 

Love, desire, connection—all of the things that make us want to stay and go deeper with someone—are not induced by that other person. They are co-created. Instead of asking whether we’ve found the right person, imagine what it would be like to be in a relationship in which both partners are mutually interested in being good for each other. 

It’s not just the other person’s responsibility to woo us, maintain our attention, heal us and help us grow. Love can do many things but it can’t do everything and neither can our partners. Love is an ongoing collaboration, and it takes everyone in the relationship to sustain and grow it. 

To dive deeper into the Myths We Tell Ourselves When Dating, click the link in my bio or go to estherperel.com/blog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel in Manhattan, New York. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Where Should We Begin is a game of stories. ⁠

Yes, stories - not just conversation starters - because it is stories that connect us, make us laugh and cry, and better understand ourselves and each other. Stories help us remember and share the defining moments of our lives. ⁠
⁠⁠
Whether you’re on a date, with strangers at a party, or with lifelong friends who you think you know everything about and don’t, Where Should We Begin prompts you to to tell the stories you’ve never told before or perhaps the ones you never thought you’d tell. It challenges us to take risks, invites us to play, and encourages deep connection in a time when we especially crave it. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
So, what’s your favorite story to tell? #whereshouldwebegin

node.text:
The state of being single is a lot more complicated and nuanced than it was when I was growing up. At that time, "single" meant "not married" and came with an array of rules and rumors. There were assumptions around what a single woman can and cannot do, and while men had the same, they still had the economic freedom to survive in society on their own. 

We know that things are different now, at least in the West. You can have a full life as a single person, with economic independence, your own home, a job outside of the house, kids or no kids, multiple partners or no partners, and so on. And yet, we’re all still confronted with the same narrow definitions of “married” or “single” at the doctor’s office and on the census. Those categories no longer feel as telling or descriptive as they once did. 

These days, we live with a multiplicity of relational identifiers: committed but non-monogamous, polyamorous, single and co-parenting, married, divorced, dating for fun, looking for a soul mate, making space to heal, or simply prioritizing ourself. And within each label, there is a story about where we’ve been, who we’ve loved, what we’re looking for now, or what we’re looking to avoid. 

So let's turn the lens on you: what do you associate with the word single? How might you like to change that definition?  What are you own biases about being single in regard to yourself or others? What’s the best part of being single?

node.text:
I’m hearing a lot about burnout lately, from friends, clients and colleagues. It seems that many of us are in need of a break right now. 

As I take a moment of vacation, I am reminding myself (and all of you) that a break is freedom from any “must do”. It’s not a chance to do all the things I’ve been neglecting but an opportunity to just be, releasing the need to produce and optimize, and instead allowing life to happen around me. By relinquishing agency, I can truly relax.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on July 31, 2021. May be a cartoon of ‎text that says '‎Our romantic partners What we expect from them حه‎'‎.

node.text:
We tell ourselves a handful of myths when we’re dating. Maybe ingrained in childhood or picked up from our social groups, these stories create unrealistic expectations, restrictions, and judgment that can rob us of the fun of meeting new people and having shared experiences.

One such myth is “There’s Only One Person Out There For Me” - one of the most limiting beliefs there is in dating, which often leads to major disappointment. There is never going to be one perfect person whose love is so powerful that it checks every box, heals all our wounds, and makes us want to delete all the apps. And putting that pressure on a romantic connection, especially early on, can prevent a dalliance from developing into something more. Perfection is the enemy of the good, especially in relationships. Why do we carry these expectations of potential partners when we know that we’re not perfect either?

Instead of looking for perfection, look for willingness to grow. Being open and willing are fundamental to meaningful growth, and couples are supposed to grow and change. Interested in debunking the remaining 4 Myths? Visit estherperel.con/blog or the link in my bio to continue reading.

🎨: @natalia_ramas

node.text:
We’re asking ourselves many questions right now as we rediscover how we relate to one another. Should we gather? Is it safe? And once we’re together, what can we ask? What can we tell? So much has happened in the last 18 months, that we long to deepen our conversations past the surface. 

For more on reconnection, listen to my conversation with @jayshetty on his podcast On Purpose.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Esther Perel on July 25, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, book and text that says 'My favorite love story to tell'.

node.text:
My favorite love story to tell is ours, @jacksaulofficial.

We were friends for two years before we were anything more. It wasn't until my very last evening in the US that we realized we couldn't imagine not being in each other's lives. Until I was faced with the possibility of never seeing him again and that possibility was unbearable.

I have had boyfriends who became dear friends, but I never had a friend who became a boyfriend. I thought if it hadn't happened it wasn't "meant to be" -- but we know now that is not how it works. :) Together, we chose this story.

#WhereShouldWeBegin ✨
